name: ArcelorMittal
title: Nippon Steel Advances Toward 100-Million Ton Capacity Target - Bloomberg
description:
Nippon Steel Corp. said it’s moving closer to its long-term goal of reaching 100 million tons of annual crude steel production capacity after its acquisition of United States Steel Corp. “It’s only a matter of time” before Nippon Steel can reach the target, Vice Chairman Takahiro Mori said in an interview on Thursday.
The company’s joint venture, ArcelorMittal Nippon Steel India Ltd., has plans to scale up its capacity in India, which will also help, he said.
text:
Nippon Steel Corp. said it’s moving closer to its long-term goal of reaching 100 million tons of annual crude steel production capacity after its acquisition of United States Steel Corp.

“It’s only a matter of time” before Nippon Steel can reach the target, Vice Chairman Takahiro Mori said in an interview on Thursday. The company’s joint venture, ArcelorMittal Nippon Steel India Ltd., has plans to scale up its capacity in India, which will also help, he said.

name: Boston Scientific
title: The top Abbott stories of 2025 so far - MassDevice
description:
Here are some the biggest stories out of Abbott’s medical device business so far in 2025: 5.
Abbott launches next-gen delivery system for Proclaim DRG neurostim In April, Abbott began the rollout of a next-generation delivery system for its neuromodulation business.
FDA approves Abbott mitral valve replacement device that doesn’t require open-heart surgery The FDA in May granted approval for Tendyne, Abbott’s transcatheter mitral valve replacement (TMVR) system.
Abbott plans to expand the system’s availability to additional EU markets in the second half of 2025.
Abbott is making an IVL play with FDA IDE nod In March, Abbott announced that it received FDA investigational device exemption (IDE) approval for its coronary intravascular lithotripsy (IVL) system.
text:
The medical device segment at Abbott (NYSE: ABT) Abbott Laboratories $131.38 0.00% Open 130.865 Day High 131.659 52 Week High 120.4 52 Week Low 88.33 continues to help drive the company forward.

It’s driven by the success of innovative medtech, including FreeStyle Libre continuous glucose monitors, Navitor transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI) system, the TriClip transcatheter tricuspid valve repair (TTVR) system, and the Aveir leadless cardiac pacemaker system. The medtech segment grew sales 12% year-over-year during the first half of 2025.

At DeviceTalks West Oct. 15-16, 2025, in Santa Clara, California, Abbott Neuromodulations’s Yagna Pathak, PhD, will sit on a panel exploring the clinical applications of connected health. Additionally, Abbott Vascular’s Chief Medical Officer, Dr. Ethan Korngold, will share how AI is shaping Abbott’s cardiovascular portfolio.

Learn more and register at West.DeviceTalks.com.

Over the course of this year so far, the company has reported several significant milestones as its growth continues. Here are some the biggest stories out of Abbott’s medical device business so far in 2025:

5. Abbott launches next-gen MitraClip, TriClip G5 systems

Earlier this month, Sandra Lesenfants, SVP of Abbott’s Structural Heart Division, announced the availability of the company’s next-generation MitraClip and TriClip G5 systems on LinkedIn.

The launch came about a month after Abbott announced a significant Medicare victory for TriClip. The company said that the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) released a National Coverage Determination (NCD) and coverage conditions for tricuspid transcatheter edge-to-edge repair (T-TEER) for tricuspid regurgitation (TR). That included the TriClip TEER system.

TriClip offers an option for those who aren’t good candidates for surgery and continue to have symptoms or persistent TR despite treatment with medical therapy. Delivered through a vein in the leg, the TriClip TEER technology clips together a portion of leaflets. It repairs the tricuspid valve and helps blood flow in the right direction without the need for open-heart surgery.

MitraClip, meanwhile, offers the percutaneous reduction of significant symptomatic mitral regurgitation (MR).

Read the full story here>>

4. Abbott launches next-gen delivery system for Proclaim DRG neurostim

In April, Abbott began the rollout of a next-generation delivery system for its neuromodulation business.

The company plans to use this system to streamline implantation for electrodes use with its Proclaim DRG neurostimulation system. It designed its new system to streamline the procedure when doctors implant them in patients suffering from complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) Type 1 and causalgia (CRPS Type 2) of the lower extremities.

Proclaim DRG targets and stimulates the dorsal root ganglion (DRG) cluster of nerve cells found along the spine. This cluster controls pain signals from specific areas of the body, including the pelvis, groin, hip, knee, ankle and foot. Proclaim DRG is the first and only DRG technology approved to treat CRPS of the lower limbs, Abbott said in a news release. It also picked up expanded MRI labeling in January 2024.

The delivery system enables physicians to carefully navigate and access the precise anatomy of the DRG when placing the electrodes. Abbott designed the next-generation system for ease of use with enhanced durability and maneuverability, streamlining implantations.

Read the full story here>>

3. FDA approves Abbott mitral valve replacement device that doesn’t require open-heart surgery

The FDA in May granted approval for Tendyne, Abbott’s transcatheter mitral valve replacement (TMVR) system.

The TMVR system offers an option for patients with mitral valves that fail to function properly due to severe mitral annular calcification (MAC). MAC stiffens the annulus ring-like structure that supports the mitral valve. This can lead to mitral regurgitation or stenosis, disrupting the heart’s ability to effectively pump blood.

Some patients with severe MAC at high risk for open-heart surgery can’t have their valve repaired with MitraClip. For this population, Tendyne delivers an alternative, minimally invasive way to replace the leaky (mitral regurgitation) or narrowed (stenosis) valve.

Abbott said Tendyne’s unique, innovative design and availability in multiple sizes allows it to adapt to a range of patient anatomies. Delivered through a small incision in the chest, the self-expanding valve replaces the mitral valve. It remains fully repositionable and retrievable during implantation, too.

Read the full story here>>

2. Abbott wins CE Mark for Volt PFA system to treat atrial fibrillation, begins EU rollout

Pulsed field ablation for treating AFib is a hot space, and Abbott joined the European market in March with regulatory clearance for its Volt system. Approval added them to the market that features platforms from Boston Scientific, Medtronic and Johnson & Johnson MedTech.

The company has already begun commercial PFA cases with physicians who previously gained experience with the Volt system from Abbott’s PFA clinical trials. Abbott plans to expand the system’s availability to additional EU markets in the second half of 2025.

Volt integrates with Abbott’s EnSite X EP system and is designed to improve workflows by allowing mapping, pacing and ablation with a single catheter. The company said it has enhanced visualization and real-time contact assessment to optimize catheter positioning.

The Volt system’s balloon-in-basket catheter design is meant to efficiently deliver energy directly to targeted tissue, reducing the number of therapy applications required during ablation. It also provides greater procedural flexibility, allowing physicians to perform procedures with light sedation or general anesthesia.

Read the full story here>>

1. Abbott is making an IVL play with FDA IDE nod

In March, Abbott announced that it received FDA investigational device exemption (IDE) approval for its coronary intravascular lithotripsy (IVL) system. With this, it launched its own bid to take share of the potentially competitive IVL market.

Johnson & Johnson currently leads the way after its 2024 acquisition of IVL leader Shockwave Medical. Boston Scientific entered the space this year, agreeing to buy Bolt Medical in January. Other companies, such as FastWave Medical, Vantis Vascular and Amplitude Vascular are making waves in IVL, too.

The current approaches for clearing calcified arterial blockages include cutting balloons and atherectomy technology. IVL, meanwhile, fractures the calcium within the artery wall. This potentially allows for vessel expansion and better stent placement. Abbott’s investigational system utilizes high-energy sound pressure waves to treat calcium blockages prior to placing a stent to achieve this.

Abbott said its investigational IVL technology builds upon its existing vascular portfolio. It aims to address the challenges of currently available IVL systems.

Read the full story here>>

name: J&J
title: Michael Johnson's Grand Slam Track: $19m shortfall, unpaid athletes and a lost backer
description:
They said: “Winners Alliance and Grand Slam Track continue to work together to recapitalize the company.
For track athletes, this treatment was out of the norm.
According to people familiar with the discussions, a term sheet was signed by GST and Eldridge on March 18.
Patrick Magyar, the founder of the Diamond League, described GST as “Grand Flop Track” in a scathing post on LinkedIn.
Under the terms of their contracts with GST, athletes would not be paid until they passed the drug-testing protocol — a 21-day process — with a further 10 days of leeway for the payments to be made.
text:
According to Michael Johnson, the four-time Olympic gold medallist and eight-time world champion, Grand Slam Track (GST) was going to revolutionize his sport and see athletes treated as “true professionals.”

The track league launched in April this year after claiming in a press release in September 2024 that GST had “secured $30 million in financial commitments from investors and strategic partners.”

Yet almost five months after GST’s opening meet in Jamaica, the project appears to be on life support. GST did not complete its first season, announcing on June 12 that it would cancel its fourth and final meet in Los Angeles, previously scheduled for the end of that month. Had the money run out?

Competing athletes, 28 of whom were medallists at the Paris Olympics, are owed millions of dollars in promotional fees and prize money. The league has missed a series of self-imposed deadlines, so far paying out only athlete promotional fees from the first meet in Kingston, but not the $3.2m prize money from that event.

This has left some agents fearing their clients will never receive their money, while others consider legal action. Based on the prize pot formula on GST’s website, Paris gold medallists Gabby Thomas and Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone are owed $180,000 and $250,000 in prize money alone respectively, while Melissa Jefferson-Wooden is owed $300,000. On the men’s side, Kenny Bednarek is owed $300,000 while Josh Kerr is waiting for more than $160,000. This is all before appearance fees.

“Everybody’s patience is wearing thin,” Paul Doyle, a prominent agent with more than a dozen athletes who competed in GST, tells The Athletic. Facilities and vendors, including the sport’s governing body World Athletics, are also awaiting overdue payments, while several high-ranking GST staff members were laid off in June and those who remained had their pay cut by 15 per cent.

Johnson, GST’s commissioner and CEO, who became a trusted and authoritative voice of track and field via his punditry on the UK’s public service broadcaster the BBC, is now scrambling to salvage his league and his reputation.

There are questions, too, for GST’s “lead investor”, Winners Alliance, the investment group described on its website as a “for-profit affiliate of the Professional Tennis Players Association” (PTPA), which had previously been co-founded by Novak Djokovic, and whose board is chaired by billionaire Bill Ackman. Its stated mission is to “equip world-class athlete groups with the resources needed to protect and maximize their collective rights” — in short, to help make athletes more money.

The Athletic can also reveal for the first time that Eldridge — a $70 billion asset management company chaired by Todd Boehly, chairman and part-owner of Chelsea in the Premier League, and a part-owner of the Los Angeles Dodgers and Los Angeles Lakers — were at one point lined up to invest in GST.

The Athletic has spoken to numerous sources familiar with the workings of GST, some of whom asked to remain anonymous when divulging sensitive information. Our investigation reveals:

Despite GST claiming in a press release in June 2024 it had “secured” over $30 million in “financial commitments”, sources close to the league now concede they had, at that stage, received only $13 million, with lead investors Winners Alliance having an option — but not an obligation — to advance a further $19 million.

By the time of GST’s debut meet in Kingston in April 2025, the league did not, at that stage, have access to the $30 million-plus it claimed publicly to have secured.

It did have a signed term sheet with Eldridge which, if completed, would have seen the fund close a deal “on or around April 1” to invest a further $30 million in initial funding and an additional $10 million later in 2025. However, this did not complete on time and, after Eldridge officials attended the underwhelming debut meet in Kingston, the fund informed GST it would not be investing in the league.

Athletes were kept in the dark about the drop in funds until June and continued to compete.

Athletes were first told the payment delays were due to drug-testing protocols, before Johnson told agents in the middle of June that unspecified proposed investors had gone cold following President Trump’s tariff announcements and instability to the world economy. People close to Eldridge deny this was their motivation for not advancing, citing instead concerns with the GST business model relayed before and after the Jamaica meet.

GST gave serious internal consideration to cancelling the meet at Franklin Field in Philadelphia on May 31 and June 1 but opted to proceed.

Following the cancellation of the Los Angeles meet, GST insisted the league will return for a second season, but Johnson is still to attract investment to cover debts in excess of $14 million.

In a joint statement issued to The Athletic, both GST and Winners Alliance insisted the league has a future. They said: “Winners Alliance and Grand Slam Track continue to work together to recapitalize the company. We remain steadfast in our commitment to bringing in new investment partners who appreciate the opportunity and promise that Grand Slam Track’s first season presents.”

Last summer, Johnson and his team signed up 48 of the best track athletes on the planet — split equally across men and women — to compete in Grand Slam Track. Johnson’s thesis was that track can feel irrelevant outside of its prime windows of the Olympic Games and World Championships, telling The Athletic in April how he had been out for dinner in Los Angeles but nobody had appeared to recognise U.S. Olympic champions Vernon Norwood or Rai Benjamin.

The meets saw participants run two races at every meet. Their combined score then gave a total Slam placing, which decided the prize: $100,000 (£74,893) for a first-place finish down to $10,000 (£7,489) for eighth place. Athletes also received support services, base compensation for participating and access to a content team.

On top of the racers, there were 48 challengers, who were invitees. They competed in the hope of becoming fully signed-on racers next season. They, too, expected to have travel and reasonable expenses covered, plus a $2,000 appearance fee. The eighth-place $10,000 cash prize meant they would win a minimum of $12,000 (£8,987) per meet. As agent Doyle says: “It’s athletes who are not the high earners that are going to suffer the most.”

The $12.6m prize pot across four meets made for a bigger purse per event than the invitational Diamond League, which this season will pay $18 million to athletes, including promotional fees, across 14 meetings.

The VIP treatment for athletes began in October 2024, when GST flew out signed-up racers and their plus ones to Malibu, where Johnson lives, for content creation, an all-expenses-paid social, and a trip to SoFi stadium in the corporate suites to watch the LA Rams beat the Minnesota Vikings. For track athletes, this treatment was out of the norm.

“Do I believe a four-meet Grand Slam series is capable of covering a $30 million expense? Absolutely,” says Doyle. “But it’s not going to happen overnight. My big concern, which I expressed to Michael, was what happens if you spend this $30 million and only recoup a million? Is that going to be a problem? He said: ‘No, my investors are here for the long haul, they see the big picture, they understand what this can be.'”

The problem, though, is it appears that GST never “secured” $30 million. Following substantial questions this week from The Athletic, people close to both GST and Winners say the initial investment, wired in April 2024, was for only $13 million. This also included the option for Winners to put up an extra $19 million, but this was conditional on GST’s operational and investor progress.

There was a belief on Johnson’s part that Winners, which has a track record of protecting athletes, might step in should it be necessary particularly as Winners had representation on the GST board. Yet Winners, which was not only the lead investor but the de facto operating partner in GST, insists it had no commitment — only an option.

By last November, Johnson had been informed Winners did not intend to take up that option for a further $19 million. Given $12.6 million had been publicly pledged as prize money — not to mention appearance fees — this created an obvious shortfall. Johnson had raised a relatively small additional amount from personal wealth, family and friends, but nowhere near enough to cover the season.

GST and Winners needed outside help. They hired PJT Partners, the New York City-based investment bank, to lead the search as GST went back to the market.

With the season due to start in the first weekend of April, attempts to raise cash ramped up in January and February. An executive at one fund approached by PJT told The Athletic they were spooked by the timeline, concerned that a league planning to launch so soon appeared to need so much cash.

PJT approached funds across the United States with a 10-page pitch deck, seen by The Athletic. It claimed 2.5billion people globally are interested in participating, following or attending track and field events, while saying GST planned to have more than four Slams in future seasons and lauding “the highest ever combined prize pool for track.” The deck hailed racers who had already been signed up; including Thomas, McLaughlin-Levrone and Kerr. All three were signed up to GST as ambassadors as well as competitors.

Discussions began with Eldridge, and Jeff Wilbur, a partner and head of sports and entertainment at Boehly’s firm, took the lead.

According to people familiar with the discussions, a term sheet was signed by GST and Eldridge on March 18. The document said that the investors “shall fund $30 million at the initial closing, which shall take place on or about April 1, 2025, with the remaining $10 million to be funded in Q4 2025.”

This money would have seen the league through its debut season and contributed to the second year. With the Jamaica meet scheduled for April 4, the hope was to complete the deal three days before the first meet began. Yet the term sheet, seen by The Athletic, was preliminary and non-binding, intended for discussion purposes only. It did not represent a legal commitment; simply the terms that Eldridge were prepared to consider.

GST’s optimism is understandable but people close to Eldridge reject the notion they pulled out; rather they argue any deal at term-sheet stage remained subject to business and financial diligence, legal and regulatory checks, and a continual assessment of the viability of the business. Eldridge representatives had flown to Los Angeles for meetings with Johnson and his team and they liked his vision, which is why they demonstrated their seriousness by signing a term sheet, but sources insist they maintained some concerns, which they say they relayed, about the viability of the business.

Their caution centred on GST’s dependence on event-day income — Eldridge were under the impression this would account for 75 per cent of its first two years of revenue. As such, it told GST at least a week before Jamaica they wished to see the debut event in person. Ticket sales had been slow, but Eldridge was told Jamaica was notorious as a late-buying market.

As the Eldridge talks continued, Winners provided a further $4m, this time as a loan, in the hope it would be paid back when or if the Eldridge deal completed. This money was needed to enable the league to continue operating.

Eldridge officials attended the meet at Kingston and then everything changed. Eldridge did not complete — catapulting GST into financial chaos. GST did not immediately tell athletes or agents. Only later in the summer, following the cancellation in LA, did Johnson say investors had reduced their commitments due to investor confidence being shaken by global uncertainty the economy experienced in March and April. This coincided with the period in which tariffs were imposed by the Trump administration.

Eldridge sources insist the reason they did not advance the deal was unrelated to tariffs, arguing that the sports economy is reasonably insulated from shudders elsewhere in the global economy.

The first event in Kingston did not meet expectations, either external or internal. GST said they sold 27,514 tickets over the three-day meet, averaging over 9,000 per day, yet the stands looked more sparse than that and Johnson claimed he had been surprised by no-shows.

As a television experience, broadcast by CW Network and NBC’s streaming platform Peacock in the U.S., the content was at times clunky. Some agents believed there was too much downtime between races and fed this back to the league. Patrick Magyar, the founder of the Diamond League, described GST as “Grand Flop Track” in a scathing post on LinkedIn. “An atmosphere closer to a mausoleum than a laboratory of innovation,” Magyar said.

Within days, a call came from Eldridge: they would not follow through.

After Jamaica, GST had a choice: they could postpone the league until further investment arrived — or Johnson could roll the dice again, hoping that by proving the concept, investment would follow. GST chose to continue.

Some who attended Kingston liked the product. Athletes enjoyed the business-class travel and their experience. The league’s hydration partner Drip Water laid on a red-carpet style entrance, which appealed to racers eager to grow their individual brands.

Agent Doyle says: “There were shoe company execs going to the meets and saying, ‘Oh, man, this is the future of the sport. This is it. This is awesome.'”

Yet athletes had no idea about GST’s impending financial doom. Under the terms of their contracts with GST, athletes would not be paid until they passed the drug-testing protocol — a 21-day process — with a further 10 days of leeway for the payments to be made. The second meet in Miami was within this window, meaning payments for the first meet were only expected shortly after that event. While 48 racers were signed up for the initial four events, some challengers were signed up between meets.

Agent Ray Flynn, who represents Kerr and is broadly supportive of GST, says: “We do not sit there as agents constantly checking if a company or a league has its money in place; we enter leagues in good faith and we trust the people we work with.

“We are not privy to the ins and outs of their arrangements. It would be naive if they have gone into arrangements without firm and binding contracts.”

In Miami, which sold out on two days, cost-cutting attempts were made. Staff were asked not to rack up additional hotel fees by renting conference rooms. Some staff were moved to cheaper hotels rather than staying in AirBnBs. The budget in Miami was also stretched by the cost of shuttles to and from the Miramar track to the hotel, as ride-share prices rocketed due to the event taking place on the same weekend as the Miami Grand Prix.

The Jamaica meet took place on the first weekend of April and by the time of the Philadelphia meet, over the last weekend of May, some agents realised payments were late. GST initially blamed it on delays with the drug-testing process.

The league’s CEO, Steve Gera, frequently took new investor calls and minor cash injections follow, but not enough to move the needle.

The league had burned through much of its cash. GST sources say the $18m it received was spent on ambassadorial fees to the small number of racers who took on that status, but also start-up costs to build the league, staffing costs, production, marketing and branding.

Some of those familiar with GST question if the budget management was as prudent as it ought to have been. The league did not, for example, hire an in-house finance director or CFO.

“Nobody wanted to ever be the person to say no to something,” says a source familiar with how GST works. “It needed someone at VP (vice president) level handling finances.” Instead, this person says daily items often crossed the desk of the league’s human resources lead. GST denies this, saying that Winners Alliance doubled up as an operating partner and that the fund’s CFO Vivek Khanna provided this function to GST.

In the middle of June, GST gave serious consideration to pulling the third leg of the season in Philadelphia. Johnson and Gera admitted to staff that funding was an issue and only 10 days out from the event, GST were still considering whether to go ahead.

Front Office Sports first reported that Robert Smith, the billionaire founder of Vista Equity Partners and a board member of GST, stepped in to help to fund the Philly meet, which was the most successful in terms of attendance, to go ahead. The event was reduced from three days to two days, while eliminating the 5,000 meters race, reducing the payday for distance runners. The Philadelphia meet cost half of what was spent in Kingston.

Agent Doyle says his first concern came when he stopped receiving replies from GST while attempting to secure his clients challenger places for the LA meet. He says: “For one race, they only had seven athletes and didn’t fill it with another challenger. They said, ‘Why bother putting somebody in that’s going to finish last place — it doesn’t bring much to meet and it costs us $10,000 in prize money?'”

On June 12, GST cancelled the season finale in LA. This had been promoted as taking place at Drake Stadium at UCLA, and tickets were on sale, but UCLA confirmed to The Athletic that despite over nine months of planning and talks, an agreement was not secured to host GST at the venue by May 2025. “It was Grand Slam Track’s focus on delivering the three preceding meets and then reductions in the fourth event’s layout and scope that were largely responsible,” said UCLA Recreation.

Negotiations also took place to move the final meet to the cheaper Mt. San Antonio College, before deciding it could not go ahead at all.

Johnson organised a call with athletes and their agents, as well as a subsequent call solely with agents. He committed not only to paying all monies owed to athletes from the three meets that did take place, but also the fourth LA meet.

A payment plan to recompense athletes was created: the Kingston prize money was supposed to be paid by the end of July and all remaining payments by the close of September. Yet July came and went without payment and no more money has yet landed.

GST published a statement on Instagram last week, in which Johnson admitted they have not met their dated timelines. “We saw circumstances change in ways beyond our control,” he said, adding that he has spent recent weeks meeting with “excited investors.”

For athletes, there are “massive consequences”, Doyle says. “Take a guy like Eric Edwards (who thought he had won $20,000 in Philadelphia). When he came out of college, he had no shoe sponsor, I was helping him to pay rent. This was his opportunity to emerge and get out of debt and make a move in the sport. If he doesn’t get paid, it’s a massive detriment.

“Or Jacory Patterson, who was working at UPS, ran really well and got second place in Miami. That was $50,000. He said, ‘Well, maybe I can quit my job now.'”

Athlete sentiment is split. Thomas recently replied to a GST post on social media by saying: “So dope! Pls pay me.” Grant Fisher said at the end of July that athletes were becoming “pretty upset.” Others, such as Kerr, have taken a more patient approach, acknowledging slow payments in other sports.

“You’ve got a big mixed bag,” Doyle says. “Some agents are out for blood and want to take legal action immediately. Others are saying ‘Hey, let’s give them an opportunity and see.’ And others are saying ‘They tried, let’s see if there’s a way we can support them and get this thing to continue.”

Flynn says: “At this stage, I do not believe it would serve us well as representatives to make threatening claims or statements. Michael has kept up his channels of communications and insists the payments will be made. I hope and trust that will be the case.”

Multiple contractors have also told The Athletic they have not been paid, while the city of Miramar is still owed $77,896 in rental fees for the use of the Ansin Sports Complex in Miami. These were meant to be paid in two tranches in April and June, according to the agreement, which has been seen by The Athletic via a public record request. The city declined to comment, while the University of Pennsylvania also did not respond when asked if GST has paid up for its use of Franklin Field in Philadelphia.

The Athletic contacted GST’s three sponsors — track company Rekortan, water firm Drip and pet food company Nulo — all of whom did not respond when asked if they are standing by GST or if any rebate or reduction in sponsorship money has been requested or paid.

Kerr’s agent Flynn says: “It’s important to be balanced. Grand Slam Track is not the first or the only event late with payments. We are still waiting for payments from the World Athletics Indoor Championships in China as far back as March. Where this is different is we know World Athletics will pay in the end because they have a track record. That is what we are waiting to see now with GST, because we have been told payments are coming. GST has received a lot more attention and scrutiny than other events who have been late previously, which may be because there were parts of the athletics establishment who saw a challenge.”

In a statement to The Athletic, World Athletics said: “World Athletics and the Chinese Athletics Federation have been chasing the Local Organising Committee (who provide the prize money) following a longer than expected internal audit of the event required by authorities in China. We are frustrated by the delay in payments but the funds were received last week and transfer payments are now being made to athletes.”

Within athletics, the rise of GST sat uneasily. World Athletics provided a permit for the league to begin and its president Sebastian Coe said the league would add “lustre” to the sport. Yet many within the sport felt Johnson talked them down in order to build up GST.

“He set himself up as the sport’s saviour,” says one agent. “But the sport did not need saving.”

Doyle says: “Feelings were hurt. Maybe there were people against Grand Slam who wanted to see it fail. I don’t think those people truly had the interest of the sport at heart. If they’re successful, that creates more opportunity for other events to grow.”

World Athletics say it is owed a five-figure fee from GST for “granting them rights to World Ranking Points as well as licensed statistics and data.”

The governing body added: “If GST wishes to apply to be part of the global calendar in the future, it will need to honour its 2025 obligations to athletes first.”

In the event GST settle their debts and return for another season, Flynn says he would likely be looking for next season’s fees to be paid in advance or secured in escrow, to avoid any repeat.

For now, athletes just hope Johnson delivers. Doyle says: “It’s a lot easier going into an investor room when you’re the legend Michael Johnson. Everyone still talks about the golden shoes. Had this been somebody else, there’d be zero faith that it would continue. But since it’s Michael, there’s some faith he can pull it off.”

(Top photo: Illustration: Eamonn Dalton/ The Athletic; STR/NurPhoto)

name: J&J
title: J&J removes some Abiomed heart pump controllers from market - MedTech Dive
authors: Susan Kelly, Nick Paul Taylor, Elise Reuter
description:
The automated Impella controllers recommended for removal have a pump driver circuit assembly that does not meet current specifications, according to the FDA’s early alert.
J&J said a review of complaints from January 2011 to June 2025 showed a 0.006% occurrence rate, with one complaint reporting a patient death.
The company will provide loaner automated Impella controllers for customer use, the spokesperson added.
Abiomed’s Impella heart pumps are used to reduce the work of the heart’s left ventricle and provide support for the circulatory system to allow the heart time to recover.
J&J acquired Abiomed for $16.6 billion in 2022.
text:
This audio is auto-generated. Please let us know if you have feedback.

Johnson & Johnson’s Abiomed is advising customers to remove certain automated controllers for its Impella heart pumps from where they are used or sold after one death was linked to an issue with the devices, the Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday.

The automated Impella controllers recommended for removal have a pump driver circuit assembly that does not meet current specifications, according to the FDA’s early alert.

The assemblies contain 25v-rated tantalum capacitors instead of 35v-rated tantalum capacitors. The difference may lead to decreased pump performance or the pump stopping and triggering an “Impella Failure” or “Impella Stopped. Controller Failure” alarm, with the potential for loss of circulatory support or death, the FDA said.

As of Aug. 12, Abiomed reported one death and no serious injuries associated with the problem. The FDA communicated the information as part of its pilot program for providing early alerts about potentially high-risk issues.

Abiomed sent an Aug. 20 letter to all affected customers recommending they quarantine and do not use the products. Customers were advised to contact the company to initiate a remediation process.

“Johnson & Johnson MedTech is initiating a voluntary recall (removal) of 69 Automated Impella Controllers (AIC) after identifying a capacitor failure that, in rare cases, may lead to decreased pump performance or pump stop,” a J&J spokesperson said in a statement emailed to MedTech Dive.

J&J said a review of complaints from January 2011 to June 2025 showed a 0.006% occurrence rate, with one complaint reporting a patient death.

The company will provide loaner automated Impella controllers for customer use, the spokesperson added.

Abiomed’s Impella heart pumps are used to reduce the work of the heart’s left ventricle and provide support for the circulatory system to allow the heart time to recover.

J&J acquired Abiomed for $16.6 billion in 2022. Since then, Abiomed has recalled multiple products and received a warning letter in September 2023 due to issues with Impella.

name: Walmart
title: Walmart Unveils New Seller Tools and Growth Plans - Abasto
description:
Walmart Marketplace Seller Summit, Walmart announced a suite of tools and initiatives designed to accelerate seller growth, expand international reach and deliver unmatched omnichannel capabilities — reinforcing its commitment to marketplace integrity and exceptional customer experiences.
Marketplace and Walmart Fulfillment Services.
Seller Advisors Program: Walmart Seller Advisors Program, spanning categories, regions and business sizes, provides a direct line of feedback to Walmart leaders.
This means faster, more reliable delivery of Marketplace items to millions of Walmart customers.
Expanding Opportunities: With Walmart, sellers have access to reach customers across multiple marketplaces — including the U.S., Canada, Mexico and Chile — while tapping into tools like Walmart Connect 3P Sponsored Ads to help boost visibility and sales.
text:
At its Let’s Grow! Walmart Marketplace Seller Summit, Walmart announced a suite of tools and initiatives designed to accelerate seller growth, expand international reach and deliver unmatched omnichannel capabilities — reinforcing its commitment to marketplace integrity and exceptional customer experiences.

“Walmart has become one of the fastest-growing eCommerce platforms by focusing on what matters most: integrity, seller success and delivering exceptional experiences for customers,” said Manish Joneja, senior vice president, Walmart U.S. Marketplace and Walmart Fulfillment Services. “Everything we’re building — from smarter tools to expanded fulfillment and global reach — is designed to accelerate seller growth and empower sellers to serve customers while driving their businesses forward.”

Walmart is equipping sellers with AI-powered tools that simplify operations, save time and increase sales. These innovations are shaped by seller feedback and are designed to help sellers optimize every part of their business — from listing products faster to managing operations more efficiently and engaging customers with confidence. Tools and capabilities include:

AI-Powered Listing Tool and Smart Assistant: Single and bulk item setup tools reduce time to market and increase conversion rates, while Smart Assistant provides 24/7 real-time support.

Seller Advisors Program: Walmart Seller Advisors Program, spanning categories, regions and business sizes, provides a direct line of feedback to Walmart leaders. Their feedback and insights help co-create impactful programs and solutions, fostering marketplace integrity and a healthy business ecosystem.

Shipping Settings and Services: Sellers who self-fulfill can automate delivery promises by region, offering customers more delivery promises.

Brand Portal: Protect brands and flag fraudulent activity with an enhanced focus on product authenticity.

Walmart is also introducing new seller incentives to help sellers compete during the peak shopping season and win more business including:

0% referral fee on all qualifying toys

50% referral fee reduction on all qualifying pet supplies

Up to 100% referral fee reductions on qualifying top-selling items across categories

By pairing cutting-edge technology with targeted incentives, Walmart is empowering sellers to operate more efficiently, stand out in competitive categories and meet customer demand, especially during the holiday season.

Related Article: Walmart’s AI Empowers 1.5M Associates

Expanded reach and faster fulfillment

Walmart is making it easier than ever for sellers to reach more customers — both across the U.S. and around the world.

Next-Day Shipping in Major Metros: Walmart Fulfillment Services (WFS) now offers expanded Next-Day Delivery coverage across top U.S. cities — including Los Angeles, New York, Chicago, Houston and Atlanta. This means faster, more reliable delivery of Marketplace items to millions of Walmart customers.

Competitive Rates and Higher Sales: WFS helps sellers streamline fulfillment at rates ~15% less on average than competitors, driving stronger results. Sellers using WFS see, on average, a 50% lift in GMV on items tagged Walmart Fulfilled and 2-Day Shipping. Through Multichannel Solutionsopens in a new tab, Sellers can use WFS to fulfill orders from their own website, social media shops and other marketplaces; new users of Multichannel Solutions can receive 30% off fulfillment fees.

Expanding Opportunities: With Walmart, sellers have access to reach customers across multiple marketplaces — including the U.S., Canada, Mexico and Chile — while tapping into tools like Walmart Connect 3P Sponsored Ads to help boost visibility and sales.

Next-level omnichannel opportunities

Walmart is creating a true omnichannel marketplace that benefits both sellers and customers. These innovations are connecting online convenience with in-store trust — unlocking new ways for sellers to reach customers by blending the digital and physical shopping experience.

name: Walmart
title: Walmart posts 50% leap in US store-fulfilled delivery sales - Yahoo Finance
description:
Dive Brief: Walmart's U.S. store-fulfilled delivery sales jumped nearly 50% last quarter amid the retailer's ongoing push to accelerate shipping speeds, EVP and CFO John David Rainey said on an earnings call last week.
Technological progress will also strengthen the consumer delivery experience, Walmart President and CEO Doug McMillon said on the earnings call.
Walmart's dynamic delivery algorithm analyzes local conditions to determine the most efficient driver routes and the estimated time of arrival for an order.
"One of the things that we've obviously got is a ton of data and it's not just product catalog data these days, it's delivery data," McMillon said.
The dynamic delivery window expansion aligns with Walmart's aim to reach 95% of the country in under three hours by the year's end.
text:
This story was originally published on Supply Chain Dive. To receive daily news and insights, subscribe to our free daily Supply Chain Dive newsletter.

Dive Brief:

Walmart's U.S. store-fulfilled delivery sales jumped nearly 50% last quarter amid the retailer's ongoing push to accelerate shipping speeds, EVP and CFO John David Rainey said on an earnings call last week.

About one-third of deliveries from stores in recent weeks arrived in three hours or less, with 20% of that portion arriving to customers in 30 minutes or less, according to Rainey.

"We see billions and billions of units at a high growth rate being delivered same day and within same day from our store deliveries," Walmart U.S. President and CEO John Furner said on the call.

Dive Insight:

Faster deliveries leveraging stores have been a priority for Walmart amid deepening competition with Amazon, another company working to accelerate shipping speeds. Rainey said in a follow-up investor call last week that the push is worth it, as quick deliveries lead to more frequent orders from shoppers.

"As they realize that they can get those things that they want and need right away, we see that repeat purchasing behavior, which makes the share gains that we have very sticky," Rainey said.

Technological progress will also strengthen the consumer delivery experience, Walmart President and CEO Doug McMillon said on the earnings call. For example, tapping more into artificial intelligence could help the company boost the accuracy of its "dynamic delivery windows," which it will offer to 95% of U.S. households by the end of the year. Walmart's dynamic delivery algorithm analyzes local conditions to determine the most efficient driver routes and the estimated time of arrival for an order.

"One of the things that we've obviously got is a ton of data and it's not just product catalog data these days, it's delivery data," McMillon said. "It's real-time data. And the way that we can put that to work to understand the context in which someone's shopping is really exciting to think about."

The dynamic delivery window expansion aligns with Walmart's aim to reach 95% of the country in under three hours by the year's end. The retailer is currently at 93%, according to Furner.

title: Five Below Q2 Earnings & Sales Beat Estimates, FY25 View Raised - Nasdaq
description:
Also, net sales and earnings increased year over year.

text:
Five Below, Inc. FIVE reported impressive second-quarter fiscal 2025 results, wherein the top and bottom lines beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate. Also, net sales and earnings increased year over year. The company raised its fiscal 2025 outlook.

More on Five Below’s Q2 Results

FIVE posted adjusted earnings per share of 81 cents in the fiscal second quarter, which beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 61 cents. Also, the figure increased 50% from 54 cents in the year-ago quarter.

Net sales of $1.03 billion increased 23.7% year over year. Also, this metric surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $997 million.

Comparable sales (comps) increased 12.4% year over year, driven by an 8.7% increase in comparable transactions and a 3.4% increase in average ticket. We estimated comparable sales to increase 8.5% year over year in the second quarter.

Five Below, Inc. Price, Consensus and EPS Surprise

Five Below, Inc. price-consensus-eps-surprise-chart | Five Below, Inc. Quote

Insight Into Margins & Costs of FIVE

Adjusted gross profit grew 26.2% year over year to $343.3 million. We note that the adjusted gross margin increased approximately 60 basis points (bps) year over year to 33.4%, which beat our estimate of 32.6%. This is primarily reflecting fixed cost leverage from strong comparable sales, partially offset by the net impact of tariffs.

Selling, general and administrative (SG&A) costs rose 28.3% to $242.3 million. SG&A costs, as a percentage of net sales, increased approximately 90 bps to 23.6%. We estimated SG&A costs to rise 24.7% year over year for the quarter under review.

Adjusted operating income was $55.1 million compared with $37 million in the second quarter of fiscal 2024. The adjusted operating margin increased approximately 90 bps to 5.4%.

Five Below’s Financial Snapshot: Cash & Equity Overview

The company ended the fiscal second quarter with cash and cash equivalents of $562.7 million, and short-term investment securities of $107.4 million. Total shareholders’ equity was $1.91 billion as of Aug. 2, 2025.

FIVE Provides Q2 Store Update

The company opened 32 net new stores and ended the quarter with 1,858 stores across 44 states. This represents an 11.5% increase in the number of stores from the end of the second quarter of fiscal 2024.

The company plans to open 150 stores by the end of fiscal 2025, taking the total count to 1,921 stores.

What Lies Forward in Q3 for Five Below?

FIVE provided its financial expectations for the third quarter and fiscal 2025, incorporating the anticipated effects of currently imposed tariffs. For the third quarter of fiscal 2025, the company anticipates net sales between $950 million and $970 million, whereas it reported $843.7 million in the third quarter of fiscal 2024. This projection is based on the planned opening of 50 net new stores and indicates a 5-7% increase in comparable sales.

At the midpoint, adjusted operating margin is projected to be 1% compared with 3.3% in the third quarter of last year. This decline reflects pressures in both gross margin and SG&A. Within gross margin, the company anticipates roughly 160 basis points of unmitigated tariff-related costs, partially offset by fixed cost leverage.

SG&A expenses are expected to be about 100 basis points higher than last year, mainly due to higher incentive compensation and increased investments in store labor, including support for additional physical inventory counts.

Net income is expected to fall between $5 million and $12 million, while adjusted net income is projected to be between $7 million and $13 million. Net income and adjusted net income were $1.7 million and $23.3 million, respectively, in the year-ago period.

Earnings per share are expected to be 9-21 cents, whereas it reported 3 cents in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings per share are projected to be 12-24 cents, whereas it reported 42 cents in the year-ago period. These projections do not take into account any potential share repurchases.

FIVE Stock's Past 3-Month Performance

Image Source: Zacks Investment Research

Five Below’s FY25 Outlook

The company updated its financial outlook for fiscal 2025, reflecting improved expectations in several key areas. Net sales are projected to be $4.44-$4.52 billion, an upward revision from the earlier stated $4.33-$4.42 billion. In fiscal 2024, the company reported net sales of $3.88 billion. This increase suggests stronger anticipated performance, supported by plans to open stores and an improved outlook for comparable sales growth of 5-7% compared with the prior-mentioned growth of 3-5%.

The midpoint of the company’s operating margin guidance has increased by about 60 basis points to 7.9%, driven by fixed cost leverage on higher sales. On a year-over-year basis, however, operating margin is expected to decline by approximately 130 basis points, reflecting tariff and incentive compensation headwinds that are partially offset by fixed cost leverage.

Net income is forecast between $253 million and $275 million, which marks an upward adjustment from the previously stated $223-$249 million. Adjusted net income is projected between $264 million and $286 million, significantly raised from the earlier guidance of $235-$261 million. Net income and adjusted net income were $253.6 million and $277.8 million, respectively, in fiscal 2024.

Earnings per share are expected to be $4.56-$4.96, up from the prior mentioned $4.04-$4.51 and suggesting a rise from the $4.60 reported in fiscal 2024. Adjusted earnings per share are likely to be $4.76-$5.16 compared with the previously mentioned $4.25-$4.72, whereas it registered $5.04 in fiscal 2024.

FIVE anticipates the gross capital expenditure of $210 million. These investments will support store openings and ongoing upgrades to systems and infrastructure. Shares of this Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) company have gained 23.8% in the past three months compared with the industry’s 25% growth.

Key Picks

Some better-ranked stocks are Levi Strauss & Co. LEVI, Sally Beauty Holdings, Inc. SBH, and The TJX Companies, Inc. TJX.

Levi Strauss designs and markets jeans, casual wear and related accessories. It flaunts a Zacks Rank of 1 (Strong Buy) at present. You can see the complete list of today’s Zacks #1 Rank stocks here.

The Zacks Consensus Estimate for Levi Strauss’ current financial year’s earnings suggests growth of 4% from the year-ago actual. LEVI delivered a trailing four-quarter average earnings surprise of 25.9%.

Sally Beauty is an international specialty retailer and distributor of professional beauty supplies. It currently carries a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy).

The Zacks Consensus Estimate for Sally Beauty’s fiscal 2025 earnings implies growth of 8.9% from the year-ago actuals. SBH delivered a trailing four-quarter average earnings surprise of 8.3%.

The TJX Companies is a leading off-price retailer of apparel and home fashions. It carries a Zacks Rank #2 at present.

The Zacks Consensus Estimate for TJX Companies’ current fiscal year’s earnings and sales indicates growth of 7% and 5.4%, respectively, from the year-ago actuals. TJX delivered a trailing four-quarter average earnings surprise of 5.4%.

name: Instacart
title: How communication teams at are using AI - Axios
description:
Some communications teams are taking it upon themselves to create AI solutions tailored to their specific workflows.
Zoom out: Communications giant Burson has rolled out proprietary AI tools to help measure and monitor the impact of corporate reputation.
Weber Shandwick is using AI tools to message test, audit how organizations and brands show up across the LLMs and create communication campaigns to capitalize on generative engine optimization (GEO).
Plus, challenger firms are leaning on third-party LLMs and AI tools to help them achieve more with smaller teams.
More on Axios: AI threatens the billable hour revenue model What news sources AI chatbots read
text:
Some communications teams are taking it upon themselves to create AI solutions tailored to their specific workflows.

Why it matters: These tools automate a lot of the comms grunt work, creating more time for the team to focus on tasks and strategies that can drive the business forward.

State of play: Cognizant chief communications officer Jeff DeMarrais recently challenged his team to dedicate a week to building AI tools that solve their stickiest or most annoying tasks. The team used vibe coding software Lovable, which allowed it to develop processes using language, not code.

The Cognizant comms team developed a tool that measured and monitored online chatter and sentiment about a company and correlated that data with the company's stock price.

They created an executive dashboard so leaders could see how their internal and external communications were resonating across audiences and they built a message cascade optimizer to ensure they were deploying comms across the right channels.

The team also created a tool to generate executive briefing documents and another to scan and select specific photos from corporate events or appearances.

What they're saying: "Our CEO [Ravi Kumar S] talks constantly about the future of work and what it's going to take to succeed in the future economies — and he's made it very clear that coders of the future are people who can master large language models [LLMs] and prompt engineering," said DeMarrais.

"And there is nobody better positioned in the world to do that than professional communicators."

Zoom in: Instacart's comms team created an AI-powered tool to automatically pull coverage based on specific parameters it set, summarize each article and draft a coverage report email the team can review.

This tool has reduced time spent on new clips by more than 75% and costs by 60%, says Instacart chief corporate affairs officer Dani Dudeck.

"Across the entire team, we're identifying time sinks and turning those tedious tasks into more efficient processes, so we can put our talent toward higher impact and more rewarding work," she says.

For example, it is using AI to automate administrative workflows like routing speaking requests, managing event attendance, RSVPs and award submission deadlines.

Instacart's team also built a media response simulator using trained chatbots to test pitches and launch materials, prepare for interviews and generate potential coverage.

"Now, before any big moment, we run our messaging through the simulator to pressure-test it," says Dudeck. "Does our pitch land? What parts of the release get ignored, quoted or challenged? Where are we leaning too hard on jargon or missing what a journalist would actually want to know?"

Workday's communications team has created personalized agents that mirror specific reporters or outlets to help spokespeople prepare for interviews. They have also created agents to support and scale executive thought leadership and messaging.

And Google built an AI-powered agent that has access to all of its internal and external comms — like blog posts, talking points, statements and coverage reports — throughout the company's history, which provides the team with institutional knowledge and record keeping.

Between the lines: The in-house comms teams without the resources to create their own internal tools are relying on PR agency partners for support.

Zoom out: Communications giant Burson has rolled out proprietary AI tools to help measure and monitor the impact of corporate reputation.

For example, the Reputation Capital tool predicts how corporate reputation efforts could help or hurt stock price, sales and purchase intent, while Burson Decipher predicts the believability, virality and potential impact a message might have with a particular audience. The Burson Sonar tool uses AI to monitor and predict emerging narratives across social media and niche or nontraditional media sources.

Weber Shandwick is using AI tools to message test, audit how organizations and brands show up across the LLMs and create communication campaigns to capitalize on generative engine optimization (GEO).

PRophet, a Stagwell-owned platform, launched AI-powered monitoring tools that track changes in sentiment, predict shifting narratives and advise how best to respond. It also recently introduced GEO checklists to inform how press releases and pitches are deployed.

Edelman has created its own proprietary tool to predict and measure the impact of earned media and social sentiment on corporate trust. The agency is also in the process of rolling out a GEO tool.

Plus, challenger firms are leaning on third-party LLMs and AI tools to help them achieve more with smaller teams.

Strategic comms firm Velocity created custom LLMs to support clients' executive positioning work and test or predict how key regulators might respond to specific policy messaging.

Boutique PR agency Six Eastern has deployed customized AI models using Claude to brainstorm and draft messaging based on the client's voice and goals.

What to watch: Because AI allows for them to work faster, in-house teams are reevaluating how they rely on agency support and agencies are in turn reevaluating their business models.

"The solution is moving to deliverable and value-based pricing, so that we can both share in the upside with higher performance, faster time to market, lower cost for the client and put us in a position to retain margin," says Brian Buchwald, global chair of AI and product at Edelman.

In practice, this is likely to show up as a shift away from the billable hours model in favor of fixed retainers, along with billing based on hitting key milestones or performance metrics.

More on Axios:

AI threatens the billable hour revenue model

What news sources AI chatbots read

name: Best Buy
title: Best Buy starts layoffs, still expects tariffs hit despite sales increase - Bring Me The News
description:
Best Buy has revealed it embarked on a layoff program earlier this year as it undergoes a "restructuring" amid ongoing economic pressures.
The Richfield-based retailer announced its first sales growth in three years as it revealed its second quarter results on Thursday, notching $9.4 billion in sales from May-July, which represented a 1.6% increase compared to last year.
It says it "incurred $114 million of restructuring charges" in the quarter that coincided with "an enterprise-wide restructuring initiative," with much of the costs coming from employee termination benefits.
"The restructuring initiative is intended to redirect resources for better alignment with changing customer behaviors and the company’s strategy," it said.
It also suggested consumer uncertainty over tariffs that may cause them to be more selective in their spending, or could cause them to wait for the Black Friday sales.
text:
Best Buy has revealed it embarked on a layoff program earlier this year as it undergoes a "restructuring" amid ongoing economic pressures.

The Richfield-based retailer announced its first sales growth in three years as it revealed its second quarter results on Thursday, notching $9.4 billion in sales from May-July, which represented a 1.6% increase compared to last year.

The quarter was boosted by, among other things, the launch of the Nintendo Switch 2.

However, the company's profits fell by 36% to $186 million, and says that it will not be making any changes to its full-year sales guidance, citing "the uncertainty of potential tariff impacts in the back half, both on consumers overall as well as our business."

The company also revealed that it also made a series of layoffs during the three-month period, though it did not confirm how many people lost their jobs.

It says it "incurred $114 million of restructuring charges" in the quarter that coincided with "an enterprise-wide restructuring initiative," with much of the costs coming from employee termination benefits.

"The restructuring initiative is intended to redirect resources for better alignment with changing customer behaviors and the company’s strategy," it said.

CNBC reports that among the other factors impacting performance is a sluggish housing market that has seen customers buying fewer appliances as they delay home purchases due to high interest rates.

It also suggested consumer uncertainty over tariffs that may cause them to be more selective in their spending, or could cause them to wait for the Black Friday sales.

name: Best Buy
title: A solid quarter at Best Buy overshadowed by outlook grown cloudy with tariffs | WJTV
authors: ANNE D'INNOCENZIO, Associated Press, ANNE D'INNOCENZIO, Associated Press
description:
NEW YORK (AP) — Best Buy posted a solid second quarter that exceeded Wall Street expectations, but that was overshadowed by an outlook that has grown cloudy due to massive tariffs the U.S. is imposing on imported goods.
The Richfield, Minnesota, company cited the potential impact of tariffs on its business and customers.
CEO Corie Barry pointed out that it was the highest growth for same-store sales in three years.
A combination of innovative products, like laptops with artificial intelligence capabilities, and a growing need to replace electronics, has helped to spur sales, Barry said on a conference call Thursday.
But the overall cost increases have been much less than the overall rate of the tariffs, Barry said.
text:
NEW YORK (AP) — Best Buy posted a solid second quarter that exceeded Wall Street expectations, but that was overshadowed by an outlook that has grown cloudy due to massive tariffs the U.S. is imposing on imported goods.

Company shares slid more than 6% Thursday after the company stuck to 2025 guidance it had issued earlier this year despite the big quarterly beat. The Richfield, Minnesota, company cited the potential impact of tariffs on its business and customers.

In Best Buy’s most recent quarter, comparable sales, used as a barometer of a retailer’s health, increased 1.6% with Wall Street expecting a slight decline. CEO Corie Barry pointed out that it was the highest growth for same-store sales in three years.

Best Buy’s business had been hurt by online competition and also a return to more normalized spending on gadgets after a pandemic-induced splurge by Americans.

A combination of innovative products, like laptops with artificial intelligence capabilities, and a growing need to replace electronics, has helped to spur sales, Barry said on a conference call Thursday.

Customer behavior hasn’t changed in the first half of the year, Barry said, in that they remain resilient. Shoppers continue to focus on deals and are attracted to known sales events like Black Friday and the company’s July sales promotion.

“In the current environment, customers continue to be thoughtful about big ticket purchases and are willing to spend on high price point products when they need to, or when there is technology innovation,” she said.

The electronics industry can be particularly hard hit by tariffs because so many good are imported. But the overall cost increases have been much less than the overall rate of the tariffs, Barry said. Barry told reporters on a separate conference call Thursday that price increases were only applied to “a very small assortment” of products.

That’s because its vendors are taking different strategies, from adjusting promotions to potentially increasing prices on new products.

Barry said in May that Best Buy was taking a variety of actions to offset tariff costs, including a push on its vendors to diversify their manufacturing.

Best Buy has little control over its sourcing because it relies on vendors. The company directly imports about 2% to 3% of the products it sells. China remains the No. 1 source for the retailer’s products, but Best Buy estimates that the percentage of product cost those imports represent is now approximately 30% to 35%, down from 55% in March. That’s because vendors are expanding production outside of China. The U.S. and Mexico account for roughly 25% of its cost.

The reported net income of 87 cents per share. Earnings, adjusted for restructuring costs and amortization costs, were $1.28 per share, which is 6 cents better than industry analysts had expected, according to a survey by Zacks Investment Research.

Sales rose to $9.44 billion and also handily topped expectations.

For the year, Best Buy stuck by revenue expectations in the range of $41.1 billion to $41.9 billion and a comparable sales range of anywhere from a decline of 1% to an increase of 1%.

It also left profit expectations unchanged, forecasting per-share earns of $6.15 to $6.30 this year. Analysts expect $6.16 per share on revenue of $41.36 billion for the year, according to FactSet.

name: Colgate-Palmolive
title: How Colgate-Palmolive is Reshaping its Global Supply Chain
description:
Embedding sustainability Supplier contracts, sourcing policies and product design processes at Colgate-Palmolive are all shaped by ESG criteria.
Progress is tracked against 14 of the 17 UN Sustainable Development Goals, reinforcing the scale of supply chain responsibility.
Supply chain action on climate, packaging and sourcing Packaging is one of the most visible elements of Colgate’s supply chain strategy, having developed a recyclable toothpaste tube which is now distributed in more than 70 countries, with 95% of North American tubes converted.
Human rights form another key part of supply chain governance, with partnerships such as the Fair Labor Association addressing responsible recruitment in the Malaysian palm oil sector.
Water management is approached through the CDP Water Supply Chain Program, where suppliers are encouraged to assess and mitigate water risks, particularly in water-stressed regions.
text:
Colgate-Palmolive has published its 2024 Sustainability and Social Impact Report, which includes with a sharp focus on how supply chains can help meet environmental and social goals.

The company sets out how risk management, packaging innovation, renewable energy and supplier engagement align with its mission to "reimagine a healthier future for all people, their pets and our planet".

Crucially, the report details how Colgate-Palmolive integrates ESG issues into core business functions.

Embedding sustainability

Supplier contracts, sourcing policies and product design processes at Colgate-Palmolive are all shaped by ESG criteria. Progress is tracked against 14 of the 17 UN Sustainable Development Goals, reinforcing the scale of supply chain responsibility.

Ann Tracy, the company's Chief Sustainability Officer, says: "Our sustainability efforts also help to strengthen our business. We believe that some consumers favour brands from companies that act responsibly and will recognise our leadership in this space and choose our brands.

“We are proud of our progress so far, but there is more work to be done. We strive to be better for the people who use our products and drive value throughout our business. Getting this principle right will result in reducing our impact on the planet."

Supply chain action on climate, packaging and sourcing

Packaging is one of the most visible elements of Colgate’s supply chain strategy, having developed a recyclable toothpaste tube which is now distributed in more than 70 countries, with 95% of North American tubes converted.

By the end of 2024, 93% of packaging was recyclable, reusable or compostable. Virgin plastics use was cut by 25% compared to 2019 levels, while post-consumer recycled plastic reached 21%. Targets for 2025 include reducing virgin plastics by a third and increasing recycled content to 25%.

Colgate also invests in renewable energy supply agreements and commits to net-zero carbon emissions across its value chain by 2040.

Shorter-term goals include 100% renewable electricity by 2030 and reducing Scope 3 emissions from purchased goods and services by 42% from a 2020 baseline.

Scope 1 and 2 operational emissions are also targeted for a 42% cut.

By 2040, Colgate aims to achieve a 90% reduction in Scope 1, 2 and 3 emissions, excluding optional categories under the Science Based Targets initiative.

Colgate works with suppliers on deforestation- and conversion-free commitments, especially in palm and soy supply chains. This includes certified materials, satellite monitoring and direct supplier engagement.

Human rights form another key part of supply chain governance, with partnerships such as the Fair Labor Association addressing responsible recruitment in the Malaysian palm oil sector.

Water management is approached through the CDP Water Supply Chain Program, where suppliers are encouraged to assess and mitigate water risks, particularly in water-stressed regions. This builds resilience not only for Colgate but also for the communities where suppliers operate.

name: CVS Health
outlet: Becker's Hospital Review | Healthcare News & Analysis
title: CVS settles with Massachusetts for $12M in Medicaid overbilling case
description:
CVS Pharmacy will pay $12.25 million to settle allegations that it overcharged MassHealth, Massachusetts’ Medicaid program by not offering the lowest available prices for prescription drugs.
The lawsuit, filed by the Massachusetts attorney general in April 2025, alleged that CVS offered lower prices to cash-paying customers through a discount program run by ScriptSave but failed to report those lower prices to MassHealth, according to an Aug. 27 news release from the Office of the Attorney General.
The settlement includes a requirement for CVS to conduct an annual review of its pricing to ensure Medicaid is not overcharged in the future.
The lawsuit also alleged that CVS’ pricing practices violated a state rule in place since 1995, which requires MassHealth to receive the lowest price CVS charges or accepts from any other payer.
The case focused primarily on pricing for generic drugs and involved discount programs offered to former customers of CVS’ Health Savings Pass and pharmacies acquired from Target.
text:
CVS Pharmacy will pay $12.25 million to settle allegations that it overcharged MassHealth, Massachusetts’ Medicaid program by not offering the lowest available prices for prescription drugs.

The lawsuit, filed by the Massachusetts attorney general in April 2025, alleged that CVS offered lower prices to cash-paying customers through a discount program run by ScriptSave but failed to report those lower prices to MassHealth, according to an Aug. 27 news release from the Office of the Attorney General.

The settlement includes a requirement for CVS to conduct an annual review of its pricing to ensure Medicaid is not overcharged in the future.

The lawsuit also alleged that CVS’ pricing practices violated a state rule in place since 1995, which requires MassHealth to receive the lowest price CVS charges or accepts from any other payer. The case focused primarily on pricing for generic drugs and involved discount programs offered to former customers of CVS’ Health Savings Pass and pharmacies acquired from Target.

title: Agilent Technologies Inc (A) Q3 2025 Earnings Call Highlights: Strong Revenue Growth and ...
description:
Q: What is the outlook for NASD and the pharma market, given the strong growth reported?
A: Padraig McDonnell, CEO: Pharma grew 9%, with small molecules seeing double-digit growth.
A: Padraig McDonnell, CEO: The reduced dependency on sign-offs is noted across all geographies, particularly in small molecule and large pharma.
A: Padraig McDonnell, CEO: PFAS grew low double digits globally, but the Americas saw a 20% decline due to US EPA changes affecting CapEx spend.
A: Padraig McDonnell, CEO: While it's too early for detailed guidance, the second half of 2025 showed stronger revenue, providing a positive indication for 2026.
text:
Q: What is the outlook for NASD and the pharma market, given the strong growth reported? A: Padraig McDonnell, CEO: Pharma grew 9%, with small molecules seeing double-digit growth. NASD showed robust growth, well into the 20s. Simon May, President of Life Sciences and Diagnostics Markets Group, noted confidence in NASD's momentum, expecting double-digit growth for the full year and positive momentum into 2026.

Q: How widespread is the reduced dependency on sign-offs in pharma, and what is the impact on demand? A: Padraig McDonnell, CEO: The reduced dependency on sign-offs is noted across all geographies, particularly in small molecule and large pharma. This change has improved the velocity of replacement cycles and increased the size of quotes, indicating strong demand.

Q: Can you elaborate on the PFAS market performance and any regional differences? A: Padraig McDonnell, CEO: PFAS grew low double digits globally, but the Americas saw a 20% decline due to US EPA changes affecting CapEx spend. Despite this, PFAS remains a strong opportunity globally.

Q: What are the expectations for 2026, considering the current growth momentum? A: Padraig McDonnell, CEO: While it's too early for detailed guidance, the second half of 2025 showed stronger revenue, providing a positive indication for 2026. Tariff mitigation and Ignite initiatives are expected to drive margin improvements, with a solid foundation for growth.
