name: Colgate-Palmolive
title: Colgate-Palmolive's ESG & Sustainable Supply Chain Impact
description:
Focusing on three pillars, Colgate-Palmolive is aiming to drive social impact, help millions of homes and preserve the environment – reimagining a sustainable world.
Colgate-Palmolive’s 2024 Sustainability and Social Impact Report emphasises the company’s passion for sustainability and drive to climate action to reach net zero.
These risks provide an opportunity for the company to drive innovation and growth, strengthen brand reputation and demonstrate its commitment to responsible business practices.
The organisation has a cross-functional ESG Reporting Task Force that monitors and works to prepare for existing and emerging ESG disclosure regulations and frameworks.
“Our sustainability efforts also help to strengthen our business,” says Ann Tracy, CSO of Colgate-Palmolive, in the sustainability report.
text:
Focusing on three pillars, Colgate-Palmolive is aiming to drive social impact, help millions of homes and preserve the environment – reimagining a sustainable world.

Colgate-Palmolive’s 2024 Sustainability and Social Impact Report emphasises the company’s passion for sustainability and drive to climate action to reach net zero.

Governance and strategy

Colgate-Palmolive assesses and manages its ESG risks through its Enterprise Risk Management process, as well as identifying climate transition and plastic transition as two of the critical risks facing the company.

These risks provide an opportunity for the company to drive innovation and growth, strengthen brand reputation and demonstrate its commitment to responsible business practices.

The organisation has a cross-functional ESG Reporting Task Force that monitors and works to prepare for existing and emerging ESG disclosure regulations and frameworks.

Materiality assessments ensure alignment between stakeholder priorities and business goals.

Sustainability is integrated into risk management, procurement and innovation processes, while progress is tracked against recognised frameworks including working on 14 out of the 17 UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

“Our sustainability efforts also help to strengthen our business,” says Ann Tracy, CSO of Colgate-Palmolive, in the sustainability report.

“We believe that some consumers favour brands from companies that act responsibly and will recognise our leadership in this space and choose our brands

“We are proud of our progress so far, but there is more work to be done.

“We strive to be better for the people who use our products and drive value throughout our business. Getting this principle right will result in reducing our impact on the planet.”

Climate action and environment

Colgate has advanced its sustainability journey across key areas including climate action, waste reduction and packaging innovation, with a strong focus on creating circular and environmentally responsible solutions.

Central to this effort is packaging, where Colgate continues to lead with its first-of-its-kind recyclable toothpaste tube, now accessible in more than 70 countries and with approximately 95% of toothpaste tubes in North America already converted to recyclable designs.

By December 2024, 93% of Colgate’s packaging was recyclable, reusable or compostable, with progress also made in reducing virgin plastic use, down 25% from a 2019 baseline and increasing post-consumer recycled content, which reached 21% in 2024.

The company’s 2025 targets, set through the Ellen MacArthur Foundation’s Global Plastics Commitment, include reducing virgin plastic by one-third, using 25% post-consumer recycled plastic and eliminating unnecessary or problematic packaging.

Beyond packaging, Colgate has signed renewable energy agreements, set a net zero carbon target for 2040 and continues to mitigate climate-related risks across its global operations.

Strategic partnerships, such as those with the U.S. Plastics Pact, The Recycling Partnership and innovative start-ups, are helping accelerate progress on recyclability, waste reduction and emissions reduction.

These collective efforts reflect Colgate’s holistic approach to sustainability, sourcing responsibly, designing efficiently, advancing circular systems and inspiring positive behaviour, to reimagine a healthier future for people, pets and the planet.

Colgate-Palmolive's vision

The company has also committed to achieve various targets by 2030 and 2040.

By 2030

The company aims to increase annual sourcing of renewable electricity from 35% in 2020 to 100%.

Another target is to reduce Scope 3 GHG emissions from Purchased Goods and Services by 42% against a 2020 baseline.

Colgate-Palmolive is also aiming to reduce Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions in operations by 42% against a 2020 baseline

By 2040

The aim is to reach net zero carbon emissions across the value chain, excluding Scope 3 optional emissions per SBTi Net Zero Standard.

As well as reduce Scope 1, 2 and 3 emissions by 90% against a 2020 baseline, excluding Scope 3 Categories 9, 11 and 12 and optional emissions per SBTi Net Zero Standard.

“At Colgate-Palmolive, we're committed to reimagining a healthier future for all people, their pets and our planet,” writes Ann on LinkedIn.

“We are driving social impact, helping millions of homes and preserving our environment.”

Sustainable supply chains

Colgate is driving sustainable sourcing by working closely with key suppliers to build deforestation- and conversion-free supply chains, with particular focus on palm and soy.

This strategy combines certified materials, geospatial monitoring and deep supplier engagement to ensure ethical, resilient and transparent practices across global operations.

Through initiatives such as the CDP Water Supply Chain Program and supplier webinars in water-stressed regions, Colgate promotes water stewardship, encouraging partners to measure and manage their own water risks.

The company also collaborates with organisations like the Fair Labor Association to strengthen human rights protections, including responsible recruitment in the Malaysian palm oil sector.

In addition, Colgate actively participates in cross-industry coalitions such as the Forest Positive Coalition to drive systemic change and prioritises recycled content in pulp and paper products to reduce environmental impacts.

name: Capgemini
title: Bank of Queensland confirms loan sale, fresh agent AI partnership | Mi3
description:
Bank of Queensland (BOQ) is exploring a whole-of-loan sale process and has struck a new partnership with Capgemini to bring on AI agents and grow AI capabilities as two priority strategic initiatives in the new financial year.
BOQ confirmed it's exploring a whole-of-loan sale process for up to approximately $3.8 billion of its equipment finance portfolio.
The partnership with Capgemini is designed to simplify BOQ's operating model, digitise processes, improve customer experience, and support scalable growth.
As part of this initiative, BOQ plans to co-create an AI academy with Capgemini to upskill its workforce for an AI-driven future.
Additionally, the bank anticipates a FY25 Cash ROE uplift of between 50 and 70 basis points compared to FY24.
text:
Bank of Queensland (BOQ) is exploring a whole-of-loan sale process and has struck a new partnership with Capgemini to bring on AI agents and grow AI capabilities as two priority strategic initiatives in the new financial year.

BOQ confirmed it's exploring a whole-of-loan sale process for up to approximately $3.8 billion of its equipment finance portfolio. This move is intended to enhance the bank's capital flexibility and improve its Return on Equity (ROE). The proposed transaction aims to transfer the underlying assets, net interest income, and credit loss exposure to a capital partner, thereby generating capital light earnings for BOQ. The completion of this transaction is targeted for the first half of FY26, contingent upon acceptable terms and Board approval.

In a parallel development, BOQ has entered into a strategic partnership with Capgemini. This collaboration focuses on agentic artificial intelligence (AI), information technology, and business processing services. The partnership with Capgemini is designed to simplify BOQ's operating model, digitise processes, improve customer experience, and support scalable growth. As part of this initiative, BOQ plans to co-create an AI academy with Capgemini to upskill its workforce for an AI-driven future.

The partnership is expected to lower BOQ's cost to serve, with anticipated annualised cost savings of at least $30 million from FY27.

"We are fundamentally transforming the way we operate and how we allocate capital to support customer growth and deliver sustainable shareholder returns in a structurally challenged market. We are making transformative decisions for the long-term benefit of our stakeholders through disciplined execution of our plans," stated Managing Director & Chief Executive Officer Patrick Allaway.

The news comes as BOQ provided financial guidance, expecting to report cash earnings after tax in the range of $375 - $385 million for FY25, reflecting an increase of 9% to 12% on FY24. Additionally, the bank anticipates a FY25 Cash ROE uplift of between 50 and 70 basis points compared to FY24. However, BOQ is no longer providing specific ROE and Cost to Income (CTI) targets for FY26, citing an unpredictable operating environment and industry headwinds.

The bank's FY25 financial results are scheduled for release on 15 October 2025.

name: Colgate-Palmolive
title: Cuddly targets teen odours with Refresh Rinse debut in Australia - Mi3
description:
Cuddly is supporting the debut of its new product, Refresh Rinse, in the Australian market, with a humorous campaign approach to demonstrate the product's effectiveness against odours commonly associated with teenagers.
Refresh Rinse is specifically designed to tackle stubborn odours in clothing, with a focus on activewear.
Ashleigh Wright, Marketing Director at Colgate-Palmolive, describes Cuddly Refresh Rinse as an "odour removing fabric rinse, not a fabric conditioner".
"Cuddly Fabric Conditioners have been a fabric care staple for years, delivering amazing softness and freshness for Aussie households.
With Cuddly Refresh Rinse, we’re introducing an entirely new product, an odour removing fabric rinse (not a fabric conditioner!
text:
Cuddly is supporting the debut of its new product, Refresh Rinse, in the Australian market, with a humorous campaign approach to demonstrate the product's effectiveness against odours commonly associated with teenagers.

Refresh Rinse is specifically designed to tackle stubborn odours in clothing, with a focus on activewear. The local campaign developed by creative agency VML, highlights the product's ability to "rinse the teenager right out of them," metaphorically speaking, as it targets the odours that can cling to clothing.

Ashleigh Wright, Marketing Director at Colgate-Palmolive, describes Cuddly Refresh Rinse as an "odour removing fabric rinse, not a fabric conditioner". So it's being positioned as a new category of fabric care product, distinct from traditional fabric conditioners.

"Cuddly Fabric Conditioners have been a fabric care staple for years, delivering amazing softness and freshness for Aussie households. With Cuddly Refresh Rinse, we’re introducing an entirely new product, an odour removing fabric rinse (not a fabric conditioner!), that removes stubborn odours that cling onto clothing like activewear," he explained. "This campaign highlights its incredible power in a way that will resonate with every parent who’s battled the smell of a stinky sports jersey."

Jack Delmonte, Creative Director at VML, noted the campaign's focus on teenagers as a source of odour was a natural fit for the product's capabilities.

"Teenagers are nature’s finest source of odour. So when the team at Colgate-Palmolive designed a rinse powerful enough to take that on, the casting brief wrote itself. We’ve all seen the common ‘mode of actions’ in the category before, but we had lots of fun bringing the science into the real world with this one," he said.

The launch of Cuddly Refresh Rinse marks a strategic move by Colgate-Palmolive to expand its fabric care offerings in Australia, leveraging the established Cuddly brand to introduce a product designed to meet specific consumer needs.

The campaign's creative storytelling is intended to resonate with Australian families, showcasing the product's potential impact on consumer connection and business growth.

"Our partnership with Colgate-Palmolive highlights the power of combining creative storytelling with ideas that deliver meaningful impact, both in the minds of consumers and in driving bottom-line growth," commented Thomas Tearle, CEO of VML ANZ. "We’re doing more than just selling a product, we’re sharing a story that connects with Australian families."

name: HP Inc
title: HP Inc.'s Q3 Earnings: Navigating PC Growth and Printing Challenges for Long-Term Resilience
description:
Printing Segment: Navigating a Shifting Landscape The Printing segment, however, reported a 4% revenue decline ($4.0 billion), with hardware units down 9% year-over-year.
The Personal Systems segment's growth trajectory—anchored by AI PCs and Windows 11—positions HP to benefit from the broader tech upcycle.
However, the Printing segment's decline, though manageable for now, raises questions about long-term sustainability in a market increasingly dominated by digital workflows.
The Personal Systems segment's strength, coupled with strategic cost discipline and AI innovation, provides a compelling case for long-term value creation.
However, the Printing segment's challenges—while not catastrophic—highlight the need for continued agility in a rapidly evolving market.
text:
HP Inc.'s Q3 2025 earnings report paints a starkly contrasting picture of growth and stagnation across its two core segments. While the Personal Systems division surged ahead with robust revenue gains and margin recovery, the Printing segment faced headwinds from declining hardware demand and pricing pressures. For investors, the critical question is whether the PC market's momentum can offset the Printing segment's struggles and solidify HP's long-term value proposition.

Personal Systems: A Catalyst for Growth

The Personal Systems segment delivered a 6% year-over-year revenue increase ($9.9 billion), driven by a 5% rise in unit sales and a 5%–10% price premium for AI PCs. This segment now accounts for 25% of HP's Personal Systems mix, a full quarter ahead of internal targets. The Windows 11 refresh cycle and strong back-to-school demand in North America and China further fueled growth.

Key drivers include:

- AI PC Adoption: HP's strategic focus on AI-enabled devices has positioned it to capitalize on the shift toward high-performance computing. These units not only command higher prices but also align with enterprise and consumer demand for productivity-enhancing tools.

- Margin Recovery: A 5.4% operating margin reflects successful cost mitigation, including supply chain diversification and pricing adjustments. This marks a return to profitability after years of trade-related headwinds.

- Geographic Diversification: Strong performance in China and North America underscores HP's ability to adapt to regional demand cycles, reducing reliance on volatile markets.

Printing Segment: Navigating a Shifting Landscape

The Printing segment, however, reported a 4% revenue decline ($4.0 billion), with hardware units down 9% year-over-year. Consumer and Commercial Printing revenue fell 8% and 3%, respectively, as enterprises redirected IT budgets toward AI and PC investments. Pricing pressures exacerbated the decline, with competitive dynamics limiting margin expansion.

Yet, the segment's 17.3% operating margin highlights resilience. HP's focus on high-margin subscription services—such as consumer print subscriptions, which grew double-digit year-over-year—and industrial graphics (e.g., large-format printers for architecture and engineering) provides a buffer. Additionally, stable page volume suggests underlying demand for printing solutions may persist, even as hardware sales wane.

Strategic Resilience: Balancing the Scales

HP's ability to offset Printing weaknesses hinges on its strategic initiatives:

1. Supply Chain Optimization: Nearly all North American products are now manufactured outside China, reducing exposure to tariffs and trade disruptions. This shift, combined with $2 billion in annualized cost savings by FY2025, strengthens margins.

2. AI-Driven Innovation: Partnerships with software vendors like Adobe and Zoom to integrate AI capabilities into hardware create a sticky ecosystem, enhancing customer retention.

3. Capital Allocation Discipline: $1.5 billion in free cash flow and $400 million returned to shareholders via dividends and buybacks demonstrate a commitment to shareholder value, even amid segment-level challenges.

Investment Outlook: A Tug-of-War Between Growth and Risk

For investors, HP's Q3 results highlight a pivotal inflection point. The Personal Systems segment's growth trajectory—anchored by AI PCs and Windows 11—positions HP to benefit from the broader tech upcycle. However, the Printing segment's decline, though manageable for now, raises questions about long-term sustainability in a market increasingly dominated by digital workflows.

Key Considerations for Investors:

- PC Market Tailwinds: The mid-single-digit growth forecast for the PC market in H2 2025, driven by AI adoption and refresh cycles, offers a clear runway for HP's Personal Systems division.

- Printing Segment Exposure: While HP's focus on subscriptions and industrial graphics mitigates some risk, the segment's revenue decline could weigh on overall growth if hardware demand remains soft.

- Valuation Metrics: HP's forward P/E ratio of 12.3x (as of August 2025) appears undemanding relative to peers like Dell (14.1x) and Lenovo (10.8x), suggesting potential upside if PC momentum accelerates.

Conclusion: A Calculated Bet on Tech's Future

HP's Q3 earnings underscore a company in transition. The Personal Systems segment's strength, coupled with strategic cost discipline and AI innovation, provides a compelling case for long-term value creation. However, the Printing segment's challenges—while not catastrophic—highlight the need for continued agility in a rapidly evolving market. For investors with a medium-term horizon, HP offers a balanced bet: exposure to the AI-driven PC boom, tempered by the risks of a maturing Printing business. Those who prioritize resilience over rapid growth may find HP's disciplined capital allocation and margin stability appealing, but should remain vigilant about macroeconomic shifts that could amplify Printing segment vulnerabilities.

name: Capgemini
title: Capgemini to acquire Cloud4C to boost AI-Driven cloud services - IBS Intelligence
description:
By Vriti Gothi Capgemini to acquire Cloud4C, a provider of automation-led managed services for hybrid and sovereign cloud environments.
The transaction, subject to regulatory approvals and customary closing conditions, marks a significant step in Capgemini’s strategy to expand its footprint in the fast-growing cloud managed services market.
Founded in 2014, Cloud4C has built a reputation as a trusted partner for enterprises seeking to migrate, manage and optimise complex technology and data ecosystems.
With a team of 1,600 specialists worldwide, Cloud4C offers a comprehensive portfolio of end-to-end services, including AI-driven cloud operations, process automation, disaster recovery, data protection, cybersecurity, and regulatory compliance.
The transaction will also strengthen Capgemini’s longstanding partnership with SAP by combining Cloud4C’s SAP cloud management expertise with Syniti’s advanced data capabilities, positioning the Group as a leader in end-to-end SAP transformation services.
text:
By Vriti Gothi

Capgemini to acquire Cloud4C, a provider of automation-led managed services for hybrid and sovereign cloud environments. The transaction, subject to regulatory approvals and customary closing conditions, marks a significant step in Capgemini’s strategy to expand its footprint in the fast-growing cloud managed services market.

Founded in 2014, Cloud4C has built a reputation as a trusted partner for enterprises seeking to migrate, manage and optimise complex technology and data ecosystems. Its low-code, AI-ready platform and industry-specific frameworks are designed to address the unique requirements of businesses across diverse sectors. The company is also a global premium partner for SAP in S/4 HANA Cloud, and maintains strong alliances with other major technology vendors and hyperscalers.

With a team of 1,600 specialists worldwide, Cloud4C offers a comprehensive portfolio of end-to-end services, including AI-driven cloud operations, process automation, disaster recovery, data protection, cybersecurity, and regulatory compliance. Its hyper-automated platform capabilities span the entire technology stack, from infrastructure through to application layers, empowering organisations to accelerate their cloud strategy while ensuring sovereignty, resilience and operational efficiency.

For Capgemini, this acquisition will unlock new opportunities to integrate generative AI into cloud automation, while advancing the development of industry-tailored frameworks and intellectual property for seamless cloud management and migration. The transaction will also strengthen Capgemini’s longstanding partnership with SAP by combining Cloud4C’s SAP cloud management expertise with Syniti’s advanced data capabilities, positioning the Group as a leader in end-to-end SAP transformation services.

name: Boston Scientific
title: What's the best place to work in Massachusetts? Forbes names top 20 employers
description:
Forbes just released a list of "America's Best Employers by State," based on factors like wage parity, work culture, paths to professional advancement, and whether the employer takes action on serious issues.
This was done in partnership with Statista to survey more than 160,000 employees who work for companies of at least 500 people.
In total, 1,417 companies made it onto at least one of Forbes' state lists.
Check out the top companies to work for in the Massachusetts, according to Forbes.
Top 20 employers in Massachusetts The Forbes state rankings look at all companies that do business in Massachusetts, including those not based here.
text:
Thinking of applying for a new job? Some places to work are better than others.

Forbes just released a list of "America's Best Employers by State," based on factors like wage parity, work culture, paths to professional advancement, and whether the employer takes action on serious issues.

This was done in partnership with Statista to survey more than 160,000 employees who work for companies of at least 500 people. Their responses were tallied and incorporated into a scoring system with survey data from the past three years.

In total, 1,417 companies made it onto at least one of Forbes' state lists. Some employers were ranked in multiple states, the magazine said.

Check out the top companies to work for in the Massachusetts, according to Forbes.

Top 20 employers in Massachusetts

The Forbes state rankings look at all companies that do business in Massachusetts, including those not based here.

Here are the top 20 employers for employees in Massachusetts:

Google (IT Software & Services) – Headquartered in Mountain View, California

Microsoft (IT Software & Services) – Headquartered in Redmond, Washington

Massachusetts Institute of Technology (Education) – Headquartered in Cambridge

Delta Air Lines (Transportation & Logistics) – Headquartered in Atlanta

Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Healthcare & Social Services) – Headquartered in Boston

Trader Joe's (Retail & Wholesale) – Headquartered in Monrovia, California

Boston Scientific (Medical Equipment & Services) – Headquartered in Marlboro

Siemens (Engineering, Manufacturing) – Headquartered in Washington, D.C.

Marriott International (Travel & Leisure) – Headquartered in Bethesda, Maryland

Apple (Semiconductors, Electronics, Electrical Engineering) – Headquartered in Cupertino, California

TD Bank (Banking & Financial Services) – Headquartered in Cherry Hill, New Jersey

Harvard University (Education) – Headquartered in Cambridge

UMass Chan Medical School (Education) – Headquartered in Worcester

athenahealth (Medical Education & Services) – Headquartered in Watertown

General Dynamics (Aerospace & Defense) – Headquartered in Reston, Virginia

JetBlue Airways (Transportation & Logistics) – Headquartered in Long Island City, New York

AbbVie (Drugs & Biotechnology) – Headquartered in North Chicago, Illinois

Vertex Pharmaceuticals (Drugs & Biotechnology) – Headquartered in Boston

Starbucks (Restaurants) – Headquartered in Seattle

name: Walmart
title: Walmart unveils new seller and marketplace tools to stimulate customer growth -
description:
Integrity, seller success and delivering exceptional experiences for customers,” said Manish Joneja, Senior VP, Walmart US Marketplace and Walmart Fulfilment Services.
Marketplace Seller Summit, Walmart introduced new AI-powered tools and seller incentives to help sellers grow faster, operate more efficiently, and reach more customers.
Seller Advisors Programme: Walmart Seller Advisors Program, spanning categories, regions and business sizes, provides a direct line of feedback to Walmart leaders.
Walmart says this means faster, more reliable delivery of Marketplace items to millions of Walmart customers.
Expanding Opportunities: With Walmart, sellers have access to reach customers across multiple marketplaces — including the US, Canada, Mexico and Chile.
text:
Walmart has announced a suite of tools and initiatives designed to enhance its eCommerce and marketplace platforms. Walmart says these initiatives will accelerate seller growth, expand international reach and deliver unmatched omnichannel capabilities. The company says it reinforces its commitment to marketplace integrity and exceptional customer experiences.

“Walmart has become one of the fastest-growing eCommerce platforms by focusing on what matters most. Integrity, seller success and delivering exceptional experiences for customers,” said Manish Joneja, Senior VP, Walmart US Marketplace and Walmart Fulfilment Services. “Everything we’re building — from smarter tools to expanded fulfilment and global reach — is designed to accelerate seller growth. It will empower sellers to serve customers while driving their businesses forward,” Joneja added.

Key Insights:

At this year’s Let’s Grow! Marketplace Seller Summit, Walmart introduced new AI-powered tools and seller incentives to help sellers grow faster, operate more efficiently, and reach more customers.

They also announced expanded Next-Day Delivery in major metros and enhanced omnichannel opportunities — including showcasing Marketplace items in-store.

Smarter tools and capabilities to supercharge selling

Walmart is equipping sellers with AI-powered tools that simplify operations, save time and increase sales. These innovations are shaped by seller feedback and are designed to help sellers optimise every part of their business. From listing products faster to managing operations more efficiently and engaging customers with confidence. Tools and capabilities include:

AI-Powered Listing Tool and Smart Assistant: Single and bulk item setup tools reduce time-to-market and increase conversion rates, while Smart Assistant provides 24/7 real-time support.

Seller Advisors Programme: Walmart Seller Advisors Program, spanning categories, regions and business sizes, provides a direct line of feedback to Walmart leaders. Their feedback and insights help co-create impactful programs and solutions, fostering marketplace integrity and a healthy business ecosystem.

Shipping Settings and Services: Sellers who self-fulfil can automate delivery promises by region, offering customers more delivery promises.

Brand Portal: Protect brands and flag fraudulent activity with an enhanced focus on product authenticity.

By pairing cutting-edge technology with targeted incentives, Walmart says it is empowering sellers to operate more efficiently. In addition to standing out in competitive categories and meet customer demand, especially during the holiday season.

Expanded reach and faster fulfilment

Walmart says it is making it easier than ever for sellers to reach more customers. Both across the US and around the world.

Next-Day Shipping in Major Metros: Walmart Fulfilment Services (WFS) now offers expanded Next-Day Delivery coverage across top US cities. This includes Los Angeles, New York, Chicago, Houston and Atlanta. Walmart says this means faster, more reliable delivery of Marketplace items to millions of Walmart customers.

Competitive Rates and Higher Sales: WFS helps sellers streamline fulfilment at rates ~15% less on average than competitors, driving stronger results. Sellers using WFS see, on average, a 50% lift in GMV on items tagged Walmart Fulfilled and 2-Day Shipping. Through Multichannel Solutions, Sellers can use WFS to fulfil orders from their own website, social media shops and other marketplaces.

Expanding Opportunities: With Walmart, sellers have access to reach customers across multiple marketplaces — including the US, Canada, Mexico and Chile. At the same time tapping into tools like Walmart Connect 3P Sponsored Ads to help boost visibility and sales.

Next-level omnichannel opportunities

Walmart is creating a true omnichannel marketplace that benefits both sellers and customers. These innovations are connecting online convenience with in-store trust. The company says unlocking new ways for sellers to reach customers by blending the digital and physical shopping experience.

In-Store Digital Discovery

In April, Walmart opened its new Cypress, Texas, location, which features digital QR codes throughout the store. These codes allow customers to access digital tools, services and an extended online assortment. Walmart is bringing the extended Marketplace aisle into stores, starting with a few items on display. Customers can purchase through the Walmart app and even have their items professionally installed.

As Walmart Marketplace continues to evolve, these new investments underscore the company’s commitment to empowering sellers, enabling global expansion and delivering seamless omnichannel experiences for customers everywhere.

By leveraging advanced technology, expanding fulfilment capabilities and deepening integration between online and in-store shopping, Walmart is building a marketplace ecosystem where sellers of all sizes can thrive — and customers can discover even more value and convenience.

Last year, Walmart said eCommerce accounted for 18% of its global sales, up from 11% five years prior. The retailer also said it lowered its delivery costs by 20% in the previous quarter for the US business. Furthermore, its US marketplace revenue grew 37% year over year in the fourth quarter of last year, ending February.

Enterprise Times: What this means for business

Several years ago, Walmart fully embraced digital rather than become just another retail website outlet. The company adopted key strategies to enhance its online business including expanding delivery services, leveraging physical stores for online fulfilment, and acquiring other e-commerce businesses.

The company also focuses on its subscription service, Walmart+, and uses artificial intelligence to improve its online catalogue and customer experience. So, the company’s latest announcements are a continuation of this particular journey. This includes AI-powered tools, expanded fulfilment to major metro cities, and new incentives that equip Marketplace sellers to grow faster and reach more customers.

Walmart says all the recently announced developments are geared to support seller growth. To empower sellers to serve customers while driving their businesses forward. The smarter tools, more sophisticated fulfilment and providing global reach will definitely enable sellers to support and build customer base. It will be interesting to see how other possible competitors to Walmart – Shopify, Amazon, Alibaba, Target, and eBay will react to these changes.

These platforms compete by offering vast product selections, strategic pricing, and strong logistical capabilities. Though they often differentiate themselves through specialised niches.

However, none of these players have the high street physical reach and presence of Walmart. As a result, it’s the continued integration of the digital and physical space which makes this announcement interesting. Walmart appears to be attempting to create a true omnichannel marketplace that could potentially support both sellers and customers.

name: Agilent
title: Igniting customer-centric growth: A conversation with Padraig McDonnell of Agilent Technologies
description:
AsianScientist (Aug. 28, 2025) – Agilent Technologies is no stranger to transformation.
Padraig McDonnell, president and CEO of Agilent, discusses the company’s evolving priorities, Singapore’s strategic role and the multiplier effect of partnership.
Why was it important to expand into Southeast Asia, and how has this proved beneficial for both Agilent and Singapore?
Southeast Asia, and Asia more broadly, is a fast-growing and diverse region.
— Source: Agilent Technologies Disclaimer: This article does not necessarily reflect the views of AsianScientist or its staff.
text:
AsianScientist (Aug. 28, 2025) – Agilent Technologies is no stranger to transformation. For more than two decades, the scientific-instruments leader has grown its footprint in Singapore from regional base to globally recognized innovation hub—one of only five local facilities named by the World Economic Forum as a Lighthouse for advanced manufacturing.

Now, with a newly launched enterprise-wide transformation called Ignite, Agilent is sharpening its customer focus and doubling down on collaboration, digitalization and agility. Padraig McDonnell, president and CEO of Agilent, discusses the company’s evolving priorities, Singapore’s strategic role and the multiplier effect of partnership.

1. Agilent has had a strong presence in Singapore for over 25 years. Why was it important to expand into Southeast Asia, and how has this proved beneficial for both Agilent and Singapore?

Singapore has played a huge role in Agilent’s growth story. At the highest level, we’re here to bring great science to life, and that comes to life through our deep focus on customers and enabling outcomes in life sciences, diagnostics and applied markets. Southeast Asia, and Asia more broadly, is a fast-growing and diverse region.

Singapore has been an amazing hub in Asia for us. We have over 600 skilled scientists, engineers and other employees here and a 172,000 square foot facility. Over the years, we’ve expanded from automation to mass spectrometry solutions. In 2017, our investment of S$85 million in manufacturing and research activities embodies the trust we have in Singapore’s innovation ecosystem.

What makes Singapore especially attractive is the combination of geographic advantage, world-class infrastructure, pro-innovation policies and strong IP protection. Above all, it is the talent and capability—we value Singapore’s focus on developing talent in both scientific areas and leadership.

2. Agilent recently launched its Ignite transformation. What is the strategic vision behind it and how will customers benefit?

It’s a company-wide transformation designed to help us scale more effectively and serve customers better. The strategy is centered on markets and customers, not just products, and that shift helps us stay aligned with what matters most to the people we serve.

We have a long-range plan of 5 to 7% core revenue growth annually and double-digit earnings per share (EPS) growth. Ignite is also about how we operate. We want to simplify global processes, reduce complexity and build a more agile value chain.

For customers, this means shorter lead times, greater consistency and quality, and faster response to their needs. It also means faster product launches and co-innovation. For instance, in areas like PFAS analysis or biopharma workflows, we’re accelerating how quickly analytical instruments reach the hands of researchers.

3. Agilent has launched several collaborative projects here with partners like NUS, NTU, NCCS and NUH. Why are such partnerships so important in the clinical lab technology space?

Partnerships bring complementary strengths together across academic rigour, clinical insight and technological expertise. That’s really powerful in the clinical-laboratory space, where speed and precision can directly impact patient outcomes.

Take our collaboration with NUS Medicine and NUH. We launched a S$38 million translational R&D hub in 2019 to boost clinical diagnostics and testing through biochemical innovation and techniques. The alliance has since produced over 95 scientific publications and more than 50 local and international partnerships. More recently, we partnered with NCCS to accelerate genomic profiling of Asian-prevalent cancers using our fully automated NGS library prep systems.

We’re also working with NUS Medicine to support cardiovascular and metabolic disease research through the new Centre of Excellence in Cell Metabolism. These are all structured, outcome-oriented collaborations that bring science from bench to bedside.

The way I look at it is: The world is our laboratory. Great ideas don’t come from Agilent alone. By building the right partnerships among government, industry and academia in key areas of research, we can accelerate science advancement and advance the quality of life.

4. How do these partnerships ultimately improve Agilent’s offerings for customers?

Our partnerships close the gap between innovation and implementation. Working with leading clinicians and researchers enables us to design technologies that fit real-world lab workflows. That makes our solutions more relevant and easier to adopt.

It also speeds up the feedback loop. We can test, validate and refine solutions in partnership with our collaborators, which shortens time-to-market and ensures that customers benefit from scientific advances sooner.

Another important aspect is local responsiveness. These partnerships deepen our understanding of market needs in Asia and help us provide more tailored support in many facets — from product design to service to education.

Going forward, I think what we’re going to see is even faster connection with customers around some of the most difficult challenges we have in our world.

5. Agilent is also pushing forward with scalable AI and digital-lab solutions. What changes should customers expect?

Through our Global Solution Development Center in Singapore and beyond, we’ve built a comprehensive digital-lab ecosystem that transforms research labs’ potential into peak performance.

Our focus spans four key optimization areas: data, instruments, the lab environment and the broader enterprise. By integrating AI-driven insights with connected technologies, we simplify complex workflows, automate processes and enhance data accuracy across research and production.

Scientists can expect more predictive analytics, seamless instrument connectivity and improved solutions that reduce labor-intensive workflows and variability. Harnessing Fourth Industrial Revolution (4IR) technologies, we drive efficiency and sustainability—whether it’s how our instruments work or the way we build them. Our commitment is demonstrated through four smart factories recognized by the World Economic Forum for their breakthroughs in scaling 4IR.

It’s very clear that in today’s competitive landscape, digitalization is no longer a “nice-to-have.” Digitalization is foundational to how labs perform and we’re proud to help our customers lead that transition.

6. Looking ahead, what’s your vision for Agilent in the next five years?

We strive to be even more customer-centric. That’s the core of everything we’re doing. We’re continuing to invest in innovation—both organic and through M&A, and we’re expanding into high-growth adjacencies.

We’re also enabling greater automation and enhancing our software capabilities to support labs around the world. The goal is to make it easier for customers to solve complex challenges, whether that’s speeding up therapeutic development or detecting microplastics more effectively.

Ultimately, we’re building an enduring company that can help accelerate scientific progress while staying deeply connected to the people who use our technologies every day.

—

Source: Agilent Technologies

Disclaimer: This article does not necessarily reflect the views of AsianScientist or its staff.

name: HP Inc
title: Nvidia and Snowflake figures good, HP stable, CrowdStrike poor - Techzine Global
authors: Mels Dees, Coen van Eenbergen, Sander Almekinders
description:
While Nvidia and Snowflake exceeded expectations and raised their forecasts, HP presented solid results, and CrowdStrike struggled with the aftermath of its infamous Windows outage.
Nvidia saw revenue in the second quarter of fiscal 2026 increase by 56 percent to $46.7 billion, exceeding market expectations.
HP shares fall HP Inc. reported a 3.1 percent increase in revenue to $13.9 billion, higher than expected.
CEO Enrique Lores emphasized that HP had achieved revenue growth for the fifth consecutive quarter, primarily driven by Personal Systems and a strong performance in growth regions.
Good results for Snowflake Snowflake raised its annual forecast for product revenue from $4.33 billion to $4.40 billion.
text:
The latest quarterly figures from several leading US technology companies paint a mixed picture. While Nvidia and Snowflake exceeded expectations and raised their forecasts, HP presented solid results, and CrowdStrike struggled with the aftermath of its infamous Windows outage.

Nvidia saw revenue in the second quarter of fiscal 2026 increase by 56 percent to $46.7 billion, exceeding market expectations. Profits and margins were also higher than predicted. The data center division, with its new Blackwell chips, posted 17 percent quarter-on-quarter growth. For the current quarter, the company is targeting revenue of $54 billion, slightly above consensus but below the most optimistic estimates. Investors had expected more: the stock fell 3 percent after hours. CEO Jensen Huang spoke of an unprecedented wave of investment in AI infrastructure, which will require trillions of dollars worldwide in the years to come.

HP shares fall

HP Inc. reported a 3.1 percent increase in revenue to $13.9 billion, higher than expected. Net profit climbed to $763 million, or $0.80 per share. On an adjusted basis, the $0.75 figure was exactly in line with analysts’ forecasts. CEO Enrique Lores emphasized that HP had achieved revenue growth for the fifth consecutive quarter, primarily driven by Personal Systems and a strong performance in growth regions. Nevertheless, the stock fell 1.9 percent in after-hours trading.

Good results for Snowflake

Snowflake raised its annual forecast for product revenue from $4.33 billion to $4.40 billion. In the second quarter, product revenue totaled $1.09 billion, in line with expectations, while remaining performance obligations increased 33 percent to $6.9 billion. CEO Sridhar Ramaswamy highlighted the strong growth of Microsoft Azure within the platform, particularly in the EMEA region. Analysts view Snowflake as a logical choice for companies seeking to centralize their AI infrastructure. The stock rose 13 percent in after-hours trading.

CrowdStrike struggles with outage

CrowdStrike reported revenue growth of 21 percent to $1.17 billion in the second quarter, above market expectations, and adjusted earnings of 93 cents per share, well above forecasts. However, the outlook fell short: for the third quarter, the company expects revenue of $1.21 to $1.22 billion, slightly below analysts’ expectations. The company is still dealing with the fallout from last year’s Windows outage and anticipates additional payments and revenue impact from incentives that customers had to retain. CFO Burt Podbere stated that the outage will incur approximately $51 million in costs this quarter. The stock lost nearly 3 percent in after-hours trading.

Taken together, the results show how AI and cloud continue to drive growth at Nvidia and Snowflake, while HP is performing steadily, and CrowdStrike is still recovering from reputational and revenue pressure after a failed update.

name: HP Inc
title: HP Inc (HPQ) Q3 2025 Earnings Call Highlights: Strong Personal Systems Growth Amid ...
description:
The company achieved double-digit growth in key growth areas, including AI PCs and advanced compute solutions.
The Personal Systems segment saw a 6% revenue growth year over year, driven by strong demand for AI PCs and Windows 11 refresh.
Enrique Lores, HP Inc's CEO, added that most products sold in the US are now manufactured outside China, which helps mitigate future tariff impacts.
A: Enrique Lores confirmed that AI PCs carry a 5% to 10% price increase over similar non-AI units.
A: Enrique Lores explained that the Q3 margin decline was due to lower supplies sales, a seasonal pattern similar to last year.
text:
Release Date: August 27, 2025

For the complete transcript of the earnings call, please refer to the full earnings call transcript.

Positive Points

HP Inc (HPQ, Financial) delivered a fifth consecutive quarter of growth, with top-line revenue increasing 3% year over year.

The company achieved double-digit growth in key growth areas, including AI PCs and advanced compute solutions.

HP Inc (HPQ) successfully mitigated higher trade-related costs by diversifying manufacturing and implementing cost reductions.

The Personal Systems segment saw a 6% revenue growth year over year, driven by strong demand for AI PCs and Windows 11 refresh.

HP Inc (HPQ) is on track to achieve $2 billion in future-ready gross annualized savings by the end of fiscal year 2025.

Negative Points

Print revenue declined 3% in constant currency, with a softer-than-expected demand in the office segment.

The company faced a more aggressive pricing environment in the Print business, impacting profitability.

Gross margin decreased year over year due to a higher mix from Personal Systems and increased trade-related costs.

The Print segment experienced market-driven hardware declines in both consumer and commercial categories.

HP Inc (HPQ) noted that some companies are delaying IT projects, affecting software demand in hybrid systems.

Q & A Highlights

Q: Can you quantify the impact of tariff-related costs in the quarter and how much was offset?

A: Karen Parkhill, HP Inc's Chief Financial Officer, explained that they made significant progress in mitigating tariff costs through supply chain optimization, cost reduction, and pricing actions. They managed to offset the majority of these costs in Q3, delivering EPS slightly above the midpoint of their guidance. Enrique Lores, HP Inc's CEO, added that most products sold in the US are now manufactured outside China, which helps mitigate future tariff impacts.

Q: With many enterprises announcing return-to-office initiatives, why hasn't there been an improvement in the Print business outlook?

A: Enrique Lores noted that enterprises are prioritizing investments in areas like AI and PCs over Print, impacting short-term hardware sales. However, the number of pages printed remains stable, indicating that demand for printers will eventually return as companies need to ensure employees have the right tools.

Q: Do AI PCs have a higher ASP or margin profile compared to non-AI PCs?

A: Enrique Lores confirmed that AI PCs carry a 5% to 10% price increase over similar non-AI units. The demand for AI PCs is driven by applications taking advantage of their capabilities, and HP is seeing strong growth in this category.

Q: What gives you confidence in the continued strength of the PC market, given recent strong growth?

A: Enrique Lores highlighted the ongoing Windows 11 refresh and AI PC adoption as key drivers. The funnel for Windows 11 is improving, and with only slightly more than 50% of the installed base converted, there is still significant potential for growth. Karen Parkhill added that they expect sequential revenue growth in line with prior-year seasonality.

Q: How do you view the future of Print margins given recent volatility?

A: Enrique Lores explained that the Q3 margin decline was due to lower supplies sales, a seasonal pattern similar to last year. They expect Print margins to be at the top end of their range in Q4, driven by higher supplies volumes and disciplined pricing. Long-term, they aim to maintain their current margin ranges while focusing on profitable unit placements and cost management.

name: Albertsons
title: Kroger Announces Corporate Layoffs, Structural Changes - Total Retail
description:
Kroger will lay off nearly 1,000 corporate employees as part of structural changes to its administrative teams across the U.S., multiple news outlets reported Tuesday.
According to an internal memo obtained by the Los Angeles Times and other news outlets, the grocer is moving to trim costs and simplify its business model.
The affected associates are all corporate employees who do not work in stores, manufacturing facilities or distribution centers, a company spokesperson told the Los Angeles Times on Tuesday.
The memo said Kroger, which also owns Harris Teeter and King Soopers, will prioritize reducing prices, opening new stores, and adding jobs at the store level.
During that announcement — revealed during the company's first-quarter earnings call — Kroger said no layoffs were planned as a result of the closings.
text:
Kroger will lay off nearly 1,000 corporate employees as part of structural changes to its administrative teams across the U.S., multiple news outlets reported Tuesday. According to an internal memo obtained by the Los Angeles Times and other news outlets, the grocer is moving to trim costs and simplify its business model. The affected associates are all corporate employees who do not work in stores, manufacturing facilities or distribution centers, a company spokesperson told the Los Angeles Times on Tuesday.

The memo said Kroger, which also owns Harris Teeter and King Soopers, will prioritize reducing prices, opening new stores, and adding jobs at the store level.

Total Retail's Take: This decision follows Kroger's announcement in June that it would shutter 60 underperforming stores within the next 18 months. During that announcement — revealed during the company's first-quarter earnings call — Kroger said no layoffs were planned as a result of the closings.
